subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Other Languages
msgSnippet: I m curious about French. The problem with English spelling arises largely because of the heterogeneous sources of vocabulary (French being a major culprit, of
messageBody:
I'm curious about French. The problem with English spelling arises
largely because of the heterogeneous sources of vocabulary (French
being a major culprit, of course). French spelling is clearly not
representative of current pronunciation, but the internal consistency
of the orthography is much higher than in English. I just discussed
this with a French coworker over lunch, and she said she rarely has to
look words up in a dictionary when writing in French.

Ted


On Dec 18, 2007 8:40 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> tim_rice09 scripsit:
>
>
> > Wow, it's been a while since I've written anything here(Esperanto has
> > taken quite a bit of my time). I'd like to know, are there any Gaelic
> > or Welsh speekers in this group? Read added Loch and Llan to the
> > alphabet for some reason.
>
> He added them to allow Welsh and Scottish Gaelic place names to be
> pronounced "correctly" -- that is, more or less as they were in the
> original language -- in an anglophone context.
>
> A plausible representation of Welsh could be managed with QS as we know
> it, but Scottish Gaelic would require some additional consonant letters.
>
> However, the real targets for QS adaptations would not be any Celtic
> language but something like French.
>
> --
> Ambassador Trentino: I've said enough. I'm a man of few words.
> Rufus T. Firefly: I'm a man of one word: scram!
> --Duck Soup John Cowan <cowan@...>
>
